description:
Saccopteryx leptura, commonly known as the Lesser Yellow Bat or Lesser Yellow Sac-winged Bat, is a species of bat found in South and Central America. It belongs to the family Emballonuridae, which are small to medium-sized bats with distinctive wing pouches.

The Saccopteryx leptura has a small body size, with a head-and-body length of around 5-6 cm and a wingspan of approximately 25-30 cm. Its fur is typically yellowish-brown in color, and it has large, rounded ears and a short, broad muzzle. The species is known for its unique wing pouches, which are located on the underside of its wings and are used for roosting and social interactions.

Saccopteryx leptura is primarily insectivorous, feeding on a variety of small insects such as moths, flies, and beetles. It is a colonial species, often roosting in large groups in caves, hollow trees, and man-made structures. The species is widely distributed across its range, which includes parts of Mexico, Central America, and northern South America.

Conservation-wise, the Saccopteryx leptura is classified as Least Concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), as it has a large population and is not facing significant threats across its range.
